content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is continuous on the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> consists of a line segment and a quarter circle, as shown in the figure above. On the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open parenthesis, f of x, close parenthesis, squared, equals 4 x minus x squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. The function <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is defined by <math alttext="g of x, equals the integral from 2 to x, of, f of t, d t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find <math alttext="g of 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g of 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is continuous on the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> consists of a line segment and a quarter circle, as shown in the figure above. On the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open parenthesis, f of x, close parenthesis, squared, equals 4 x minus x squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. The function <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is defined by <math alttext="g of x, equals the integral from 2 to x, of, f of t, d t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find <math alttext="g of 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g of 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Find <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 2, of, the fraction with numerator g of x, and denominator the sine of, open parenthesis, x minus 2, close parenthesis, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answer.

(c) Find <math alttext="the integral from 1 to 2, of, the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator, open parenthesis, f of x, close parenthesis, squared, end fraction, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo stretchy="true">∫</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Let <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a differentiable function on the interval <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 3, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="h of 0 equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="h of 3 equals negative 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="h of x, is less than f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for all <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, 0 comma 3, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>. Let <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the region enclosed by the graphs of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the interval <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 3, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write, but do not evaluate, an expression involving one or more integrals that gives the perimeter of region <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.7: Using L'Hospital's Rule for Determining Limits of Indeterminate Forms

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Identify mathematical information from graphical, numerical, analytical, and/or verbal representations.
